items.title: Be contrarian: Just ‘hold’ the right stocks & outlive Trump. 11 stocks from different sectors which fit the bill for a long-term investor
items.description: For all those rattled by volatility, here’s a history lesson. 2008: The global financial crisis crushes risk assets. 2013: The “taper tantrum” punishes emerging market currencies and equities; domestic panic about current account deficits and inflation make quality stocks look dangerous. Late 2016: Demonetization. March 2020: Covid slams markets in weeks. 2022: Ukraine war triggers another bout of fear. The pattern is clear: Shocks arrive, stock prices wobble, strong businesses adjust, and time repairs the damage. The bottom line: Crises create noise, but strong businesses not only survive, but grow. And investors who hold on to good stocks are the ones who make money.

items.title: Pharma Index Down 2%, but Selloff could be an 'Exaggeration'
items.description: Nifty's Pharma index saw a decline after US President Trump announced a 100 percent tariff on branded drugs from October 1. Analysts noted India's limited exposure to patented drugs in the US market. Most Indian firms focus on generic medicines, which are not affected by the new tariff. Major Indian players also operate manufacturing facilities within the United States.

items.title: Bears capture spooked D-Street for 6th session running
items.description: Indian equity indices extended their longest losing streak in FY26 for a sixth consecutive session, driven by new US tariffs on drugs and trucks, increased H-1B visa fees, and Accenture's cautious outlook. This battered investor sentiment, leading to broad-based selling across sectors and a surging fear gauge. The rupee also traded near its record low.

items.title: US stocks end higher after as-expected inflation data; S&P 500, Nasdaq post weekly declines
items.description: US stocks closed higher Friday on expected inflation data, yet posted weekly losses, ending winning streaks for S&P 500 and Nasdaq. Investors are weighing the Federal Reserve's future rate cuts against a stronger economy and upcoming earnings season. New tariffs and mixed signals from Fed officials added to market uncertainty, with key employment data due next week.

items.title: Wall Street Week Ahead: Investors look to jobs data to support rate-cut path, pricey stock market
items.description: Next week's U.S. jobs data holds significance for markets. It needs to indicate a cooling labor market. This supports further interest rate cuts. It must not trigger recession concerns. The Federal Reserve plans more rate reductions this year. High stock valuations create market vulnerability. A potential government shutdown also looms.

items.title: European shares recover from three-week lows, but weekly momentum fizzles
items.description: European stocks rebounded Friday, with the STOXX 600 gaining 0.8%, largely driven by financials and industrials. Steel producers surged on reports of potential EU tariffs against Chinese imports. Healthcare stocks ended flat despite new US drug tariffs, as the impact was already priced in. US inflation data eased fears of delayed rate cuts, while InterContinental Hotels Group saw significant gains.

items.title: Market outlook cautious as FIIs, global risks keep investors on edge: Sunil Subramaniam
items.description: Market direction remains uncertain amid external policy risks, currency volatility, and crude price fluctuations. Short-term focus is on consumer sectors, while long-term opportunities lie in real estate, industrials, and PSU banks driven by consumption and private capex.

items.title: HSBC picks 11 stocks to ride FII return after 12-month absence. Do you own any?
items.description: Just a day after HSBC upgraded Indian equities to ‘Overweight’ from ‘Neutral’ on the back of attractive valuations, supportive government policies and resilient domestic flows, the brokerage has now said that foreign institutional investors (FIIs) are likely to make a comeback after a lengthy 12-month absence. To capitalise on this trend, HSBC has named 11 stocks as its top picks. Here’s the full list!

items.title: Trump’s dual shocks thwart bets on Indian stock market rebound
items.description: Donald Trump's recent actions, including H-1B visa changes and pharmaceutical tariffs, have dealt a significant blow to Indian stock markets, thwarting a nascent rebound. This has led to foreign investor sell-offs and increased US-India tensions, resetting expectations for a year-end rally and raising concerns about economic growth.

items.title: Skin in the game matters: Samir Arora suggests investors to question fund managers on personal exposure
items.description: Helios Capital’s Samir Arora urged investors to question fund managers, AMCs, and brokers about their personal stakes in recommended strategies, stressing the need for transparency, accountability, and “skin in the game” in investment decisions. For traders, the same principle applies and  they should ask their broker- how much of his personal wealth he is hedging via weekly options and futures.

items.title: Concurrent Losers: 10 Nifty stocks decline for 5 consecutive sessions
items.description: Over the last five trading sessions ending on September 26, the Nifty benchmark index dropped by 2.65%, closing at 24,654. This decline was continuous across all five sessions. During this period, 10 stocks within the Nifty50 index recorded losses in each of the five consecutive sessions. (Data Source: ACE Equity)

items.title: Defying gravity: Tata Investment, Zuari Industries lead smallcaps in weekly top 10, rise up to 31%
items.description: Smallcap stocks saw declines of up to 77% in the week gone by, with over 900 stocks in the BSE Smallcap index closing in the red. However, there was bright spot—more than 140 stocks ended positive, including 24 that gained in double digits. Here are the top 10 weekly performers:

items.title: Market bloodbath: 440 of BSE 500 stocks end week in red, 17 sink in double-digits amid IT, pharma rout
items.description: Indian markets slumped as BSE 500 fell 3.3% amid Trump’s steep H-1B visa fee hike and 100% drug tariff announcement. Over 440 stocks dropped, with IT, realty, consumer and healthcare sectors hit hardest.

items.title: Nifty drain jewels? TCS, Infosys, DMart among 5 biggies with zero returns in last four years
items.description: Once considered the safest bets on Dalal Street, blue-chip names like TCS, Infosys, DMart, Asian Paints, and HUL have stunned investors with flat or negative returns over the past four years.

items.title: Smart picks: 5 IPOs that could offer up to 20% returns next week
items.description: With markets buzzing from a flurry of listings, investors are eyeing quick gains, looking at GMPs. A handful of IPOs lined up for debut next week are indicating potential double-digit returns, with some tipped to deliver up to 20% gains on listing day.
